awd_titl_txt: IBSS-L: Procedural Mechanisms and Systemic Inequality in Municipal Law Enforcement
awd_abstract_narration:
This interdisciplinary research project will expand the scope of the National Justice Database, the nation's first multi-site database to track police behavior such as stops and use of force, and it will assess how common policies and procedures in policing influence racially disparate outcomes.  The project will promote the development and validation of a nationally standardized approach to police stop data collection, analysis, and interpretation.  It will enhance basic understanding of individual, organizational, and systemic discrimination as well as the interactions among those levels.  The project will provide new insights that will inform interventions and strategies to bridge the divide between police officers and the communities they serve.  The project will help transform the National Justice Database into a tool that can inform interventions and strategies as well as determine the success rates of strategies and interventions devised by police departments.  By studying policies, with a particular focus on those directed toward training, accountability, community-oriented policing, "hot-spot" policing, calls for service, and other deployment strategies, the project can help identify which policies are most successful at reducing racial disparities and what conditions moderate that relationship.  This knowledge will assist in reducing racial profiling and bolster equitable policing.

This project will examine how common policies in policing influence racially disparate outcomes across formal policy, organizational climate, geospatial, and community-guided police activity domains.  This investigators will use an interdisciplinary approach to identify specific mechanisms of policing that can contribute to more or less unequal outcomes.  By examining outcomes across these domains, they will provide a large multi-site assessment of how organizational policy produces racially disparate outcomes, with special attention given toward identifying how to reduce those disparities.  The investigators will draw heavily on theoretical frameworks from social psychology, economics, and sociology, such as implicit bias, resource efficiency, and social stratification.  They will trace causal chains from police department (and related municipal and state) policies (such as training and supervision) through the social and organizational attitudinal climates of departments in order to examine how these policies and climates interact with different deployment approaches (such as "hot spot" and proactive policing) to affect outcomes for citizens, especially racially and ethnically discriminatory outcomes in stops, searches, arrests, and excessive use of force.  This project is supported through the NSF Interdisciplinary Behavioral and Social Sciences Research (IBSS) competition.

por.por_cntn:
Findings (intellectual merit):

 

This project sought to identify specific mechanisms of policing that relate to unequal outcomes for community residents, creating and drawing on a National Justice Database (NJD).

 

The NJD has enabled new insight about police use of force. We measured racial disparities in police use of force with an eye toward rigorous methods and addressing disparities (Geller, Goff, Lloyd, Obermark, & Glaser, 2021; Goff & Buchanan, 2021). We also investigated trends in police use of force, harmonizing administrative datasets across dozens of  U.S. cities. We are using these harmonized use of force data in ongoing research projects.

 

The project has also led to new insight about racial disparities in policing, and situational and ideological risk factors for disparate policing. We developed theoretical frameworks for burdensome and disparate policing (Goff & Rau, 2020; Pryor, Buchanan, & Goff, 2020; Swencionis & Goff, 2017). We found harmful effects of law enforcement contact with Black and Latino children (Del Toro, Lloyd, Buchanan, Robins, Kerrison, & Goff, 2019). We found racist stereotype threat relates to officers’ support for using physical force, and wrote about racist stereotype threat in civil rights law (Buchanan & Goff, 2020; McCarthy, Trinkner, & Goff, 2021). We found that supporting social hierarchy is associated with White police officers’ use of force (Swencionis & Goff, 2021). We investigated departmental policy variation and its impact on policing outcomes across 19 municipalities.

 

The project has enabled us to understand more about policing from community residents’ perspectives. We investigated the experiences of different racialized groups in interactions with police officers and what kinds of police functions are relatively acceptable vs. unacceptable. We investigated how residents’ social attitudes and support for procedurally just policing, relate to their perception of police legitimacy. We investigated the extent to which different factors relate to residents’ support for police coercion, including social attitudes, belief that coercion works, and fear of crime.

 

Beyond the current state of policing and communities, this project has enabled us to look to the future, understanding more about public safety priorities and potential alternative responders. We harmonized calls for service data from many departments to enable cross-department analyses that will inform efforts to reimagine and redesign public safety systems to better meet community needs.

 

Outcomes (broader impact):

 

This project has enabled methodological and analytic innovation:

 

  • We collaborated with engineers to create data processing software. These streamlined data processes have increased our capacity to process large administrative datasets.
  • We improved the integrity and scalability of our data operations process by refining and standardizing a framework for analyzing police data. The new framework moved our data preparation and analysis codebases into one unified repository.
  • After delivering dozens of custom analytic reports to partner law enforcement agencies in PDF format, our improved analytic framework and engineering advances enabled us to develop an electronic Justice Navigator Assessment (JNA); to date we have delivered 12  JNAs to participating law enforcement agencies through the Justice Navigator portal (https://justicenavigator.org/). Currently four of these JNAs are available to the public, with additional public-facing reports in progress.
  • Our analytic framework is enabling us to answer research questions with police data from multiple cities.
  • We improved our Officer Survey to reflect new research questions and priorities and take advantage of technological innovation.

This project has also enabled important partnerships with law enforcement agencies and communities:

  • Through our Compstat for Justice program, we worked closely with a partnering law enforcement agency and community stakeholders to review department policies, conduct focus groups, and provide thought partnership and recommendations. We will continue to work with this agency and the community to implement our recommendations, helping to ensure that the scientific work informs policy and practice.
  • We completed thought partnership and technical advising to a different city and county through community working groups and subcommittees.
  • We are collaborating with five additional municipalities on programs to redesign public safety.

Last Modified: 12/28/2022
Modified by: Phillip A Goff
